message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: PROPOSITIONAL REASONING
Paper Abstract: Propositional (Boolean) logic is conceptually simple. It provides a rich basis for the representation of finite structures, but is computationally complex. Many current verification techniques are based on propositional encodings.Propositional representations lead to problems that are, in general, computationally intractable. Nevertheless, datastructures for representing propositional formulae, and algorithms for reasoning about them, provide generic tools that can be applied to a wide variety of computational problems. Natural problem instances are often effectively solved by these generic approaches.There is a growing literature of algorithms for propositional reasoning, and of techniques for propositional representation of tasks in areas ranging from cryptography, constraint satisfaction and planning, to system design, validation and verification.We present a model-theoretic account of propositional encodings for questions of logical validity. Validity is characterised model-thoretically. For restricted logics, checking validity in a restricted class of models may suffce. Classes of structures on a finite domain can be encoded as propositional theories, and validity in such a class is encoded propositionally, by means of a syntactic translation to a propositional formula.This provides a unified setting for generating efficient propositional encodings suitable for analysis using BDD or SAT packages.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of propositional logic:

## Definition

Propositional logic is a branch of logic that deals with propositions (which can be true or false) and relations between propositions, including the construction of arguments based on them.(no content)It is also called statement logic, sentential calculus, propositional calculus, sentential logic, or sometimes zeroth-order logic.

## Key Concepts

Propositional logic is typically studied with a formal language, in which propositions are represented by letters called propositional variables, which are then used together with symbols for connectives to make propositional formulas, and the propositional variables are called atomic formulas of a formal propositional language.(no content)Propositional logic deals with statements, which are defined as declarative sentences having truth value.

## Logical Connectives

Compound propositions are formed by connecting propositions by logical connectives representing the truth functions of conjunction, disjunction, implication, biconditional, and negation.(no content)In English, these connectives are expressed by the words "and" (conjunction), "or" (disjunction), "not" (negation), "if" (material conditional), and "if and only if" (biconditional).

## Relationship to Other Logics

Unlike first-order logic, propositional logic does not deal with non-logical objects, predicates about them, or quantifiers.(no content)Propositional logic is the foundation of first-order logic and higher-order logic.

Web search results for query: "Cryptography"

Links: [{"title":"Cryptography - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptography"},{"title":"Public-key cryptography - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public-key_cryptography"},{"title":"Export of cryptography from the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Export_of_cryptography_from_the_United_States"},{"title":"Comparison of cryptography libraries - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_cryptography_libraries"},{"title":"Category:Cryptographic algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Cryptographic_algorithms"},{"title":"Cryptography standards - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptography_standards"},{"title":"Cryptographic Message Syntax - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptographic_Message_Syntax"},{"title":"Elliptic-curve cryptography - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elliptic-curve_cryptography"},{"title":"Cryptographic primitive - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptographic_primitive"},{"title":"Cryptographic multilinear map - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptographic_multilinear_map"}]

Here are the search results for "Cryptography":

## Overview

Cryptography (from Ancient Greek meaning "hidden, secret" and "to write") is the practice and study of techniques for secure communication in the presence of adversarial behavior.(no content)More generally, cryptography is about constructing and analyzing protocols that prevent third parties or the public from reading private messages.

## Core Functions

Cryptography prior to the modern age was effectively synonymous with encryption, converting readable information (plaintext) to unintelligible nonsense text (ciphertext), which can only be read by reversing the process (decryption).

## Key Types of Cryptography

There are two main types of cryptosystems: symmetric and asymmetric. In symmetric systems, the same secret key encrypts and decrypts a message. Asymmetric systems use a "public key" to encrypt a message and a related "private key" to decrypt it.(no content)Examples of asymmetric systems include Diffie–Hellman key exchange, RSA (Rivest–Shamir–Adleman), ECC (Elliptic Curve Cryptography), and Post-quantum cryptography.(no content)Secure symmetric algorithms include the commonly used AES (Advanced Encryption Standard) which replaced the older DES (Data Encryption Standard).

## Applications

Practical applications of cryptography include electronic commerce, chip-based payment cards, digital currencies, computer passwords and military communications.

Web search results for query: "SAT solver"

Links: [{"title":"SAT solver - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SAT_solver"},{"title":"GRASP (SAT solver) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GRASP_(SAT_solver)"},{"title":"Boolean satisfiability problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_satisfiability_problem"},{"title":"Satz (SAT solver) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satz_(SAT_solver)"},{"title":"Category:SAT solvers - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:SAT_solvers"},{"title":"Boolean satisfiability algorithm heuristics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_satisfiability_algorithm_heuristics"},{"title":"OR-Tools - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OR-Tools"},{"title":"DPLL(T) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DPLL(T)"},{"title":"Davis–Putnam algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Davis-Putnam_algorithm"},{"title":"DPLL algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DPLL_algorithm"}]

Here's what I found about SAT solvers:

## Definition

A SAT solver is a computer program which aims to solve the Boolean satisfiability problem (SAT).(no content)Given a formula over Boolean variables, a SAT solver outputs whether the formula is satisfiable, meaning that there are possible values of the variables which make the formula true, or unsatisfiable, meaning that there are no such values.

## Complexity and Importance

Boolean satisfiability is an NP-complete problem in general. Despite this computational difficulty, modern SAT solvers have had a significant impact on fields including software verification, program analysis, constraint solving, artificial intelligence, electronic design automation, and operations research.

## Core Algorithms

SAT solvers are usually developed using one of two core approaches: the Davis–Putnam–Logemann–Loveland algorithm (DPLL) and conflict-driven clause learning (CDCL).(no content)Most state-of-the-art SAT solvers are based on the CDCL framework as of 2019.

## Notable Implementations

Some well-known SAT solvers include Chaff and GRASP, as well as Google's CP-SAT solver, part of OR-Tools, which won gold medals at the Minizinc constraint programming competitions in editions 2018 up until 2025.

Based on the search results, here's information about logical validity:

## Definition

In logic, specifically in deductive reasoning, an argument is valid if and only if it takes a form that makes it impossible for the premises to be true and the conclusion nevertheless to be false. In other words, an argument is valid if and only if it would be contradictory for the conclusion to be false if all of the premises are true.

## Key Characteristics

It is not required for a valid argument to have premises that are actually true, but to have premises that, if they were true, would guarantee the truth of the argument's conclusion. This is an important distinction: validity concerns the logical structure of an argument, not the truth of its content.

Validity does not require the truth of the premises, instead it merely necessitates that conclusion follows from the premises without violating the correctness of the logical form.

## Validity vs. Soundness

If also the premises of a valid argument are proven true, this is said to be sound. So soundness is a stronger condition that requires both valid form and true premises.

## Example

A classic example is the syllogism: "All men are mortal. Socrates is a man. Therefore, Socrates is mortal." The argument would be just as valid if both premises and conclusion were false. The validity depends on the logical structure, not on whether the statements are actually true.

Links: [{"title":"Boolean algebra - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_algebra"},{"title":"Boolean expression - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_expression"},{"title":"Boolean function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_function"},{"title":"George Boole - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Boole"},{"title":"Boolean algebra (structure) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_algebra_(structure)"},{"title":"Boolean - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean"},{"title":"Boolean circuit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_circuit"},{"title":"Boolean operation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_operation"},{"title":"Boolean-valued function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean-valued_function"},{"title":"Logic alphabet - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic_alphabet"}]

## Boolean Logic

Boolean algebra is a branch of algebra where the values of variables are the truth values true and false, usually denoted by 1 and 0. Boolean logic is sometimes used to denote propositional calculus performed in this way.

### Key Concepts

A Boolean expression (also known as logical expression) is an expression used in programming languages that produces a Boolean value when evaluated, which is either true or false. A Boolean function is a function whose arguments and result assume values from a two-element set (usually {true, false}, {0,1} or {−1,1}).

### Basic Operations

Most programming languages have the Boolean operators OR, AND and NOT. In the two-element Boolean algebra, 0 is interpreted as false, 1 as true, ∧ as and, ∨ as or, and ¬ as not.

### Historical Background and Applications

Boolean algebra was developed by George Boole, best known as the author of The Laws of Thought (1854). Boolean logic, essential to computer programming, is credited with helping to lay the foundations for the Information Age. Boolean functions play a basic role in questions of complexity theory as well as the design of processors for digital computers, where they are implemented in electronic circuits using logic gates.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of model theory:

## Definition

In mathematical logic, model theory is the study of the relationship between formal theories (a collection of sentences in a formal language expressing statements about a mathematical structure), and their models (those structures in which the statements of the theory hold).

## Nature of the Field

Proof theory is syntactic in nature, in contrast to model theory, which is semantic in nature.(no content)Model theory has close ties to algebra and universal algebra.

## Key Theorems

Two fundamental results in model theory are:

1. **The Compactness Theorem**: The compactness theorem states that a set of sentences S is satisfiable if every finite subset of S is satisfiable.

2. **The Löwenheim–Skolem Theorem**: Another cornerstone of first-order model theory is the Löwenheim–Skolem theorem. According to the theorem, every infinite structure in a countable signature has a countable elementary substructure.

## Related Subdisciplines

Finite model theory is a restriction of model theory to interpretations on finite structures, which have a finite universe.

## Applications

The applications of model theory to algebraic and Diophantine geometry reflect this proximity to classical mathematics, as they often involve an integration of algebraic and model-theoretic results and techniques.

Web search results for query: "Binary decision diagram"

Links: [{"title":"Binary decision diagram - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binary_decision_diagram"},{"title":"Binary decision - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binary_decision"},{"title":"Zero-suppressed decision diagram - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero-suppressed_decision_diagram"},{"title":"Algebraic decision diagram - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algebraic_decision_diagram"},{"title":"Talk:Binary decision diagram - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Binary_decision_diagram"},{"title":"Binary moment diagram - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binary_moment_diagram"},{"title":"Sentential decision diagram - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sentential_decision_diagram"},{"title":"Propositional directed acyclic graph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Propositional_directed_acyclic_graph"},{"title":"BDD - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BDD"},{"title":"File:BDD Variable Ordering Good.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:BDD_Variable_Ordering_Good.svg"}]

## Binary Decision Diagram

A binary decision diagram (BDD) is a data structure used to represent a Boolean function.(no content)On a more abstract level, BDDs can be considered as a compressed representation of sets or relations.

### How BDDs Work

The value of a boolean function can be determined by following a path in its BDD down to a terminal, making a binary decision at each node where a solid line is followed if the value of the variable at the node is true and a dotted line if it is false.

### Properties and Variants

A BDD is said to be 'ordered' if the order of the variables tested is fixed.(no content)A BDD is said to be 'reduced' if each successor of each node is distinct and there are no two distinct nodes of the same variable with the same successors.(no content)BDDs that are ordered and reduced can be called Reduced Ordered Binary Decision Diagrams (ROBDD).

### Applications

BDDs are extensively used in CAD software to synthesize circuits (logic synthesis) and in formal verification.(no content)There are several lesser known applications of BDD, including fault tree analysis, Bayesian reasoning, product configuration, and private information retrieval.

### Historical Significance

Donald Knuth calls BDDs "one of the only really fundamental data structures that came out in the last twenty-five years" and mentions that Bryant's 1986 paper was for some time one of the most-cited papers in computer science.

Links: [{"title":"Binary decision diagram - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binary_decision_diagram"},{"title":"Binary decision - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binary_decision"},{"title":"Zero-suppressed decision diagram - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero-suppressed_decision_diagram"},{"title":"Algebraic decision diagram - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algebraic_decision_diagram"},{"title":"Talk:Binary decision diagram - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Binary_decision_diagram"},{"title":"Binary moment diagram - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binary_moment_diagram"},{"title":"Sentential decision diagram - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sentential_decision_diagram"},{"title":"Propositional directed acyclic graph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Propositional_directed_acyclic_graph"},{"title":"BDD - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BDD"},{"title":"File:BDD Variable Ordering Good.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:BDD_Variable_Ordering_Good.svg"}]

## Binary Decision Diagram

A binary decision diagram (BDD) is a data structure used to represent a Boolean function.(no content)On a more abstract level, BDDs can be considered as a compressed representation of sets or relations.

### How BDDs Work

The value of a boolean function can be determined by following a path in its BDD down to a terminal, making a binary decision at each node where a solid line is followed if the value of the variable at the node is true and a dotted line if it is false.

### Properties and Variants

A BDD is said to be 'ordered' if the order of the variables tested is fixed.(no content)A BDD is said to be 'reduced' if each successor of each node is distinct and there are no two distinct nodes of the same variable with the same successors.(no content)BDDs that are ordered and reduced can be called Reduced Ordered Binary Decision Diagrams (ROBDD).

### Applications

BDDs are extensively used in CAD software to synthesize circuits (logic synthesis) and in formal verification.(no content)There are several lesser known applications of BDD, including fault tree analysis, Bayesian reasoning, product configuration, and private information retrieval.

### Historical Significance

Donald Knuth calls BDDs "one of the only really fundamental data structures that came out in the last twenty-five years" and mentions that Bryant's 1986 paper was for some time one of the most-cited papers in computer science.

Web search results for query: "Formal verification"

Links: [{"title":"Formal verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_verification"},{"title":"ISP Formal Verification Tool - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISP_Formal_Verification_Tool"},{"title":"Formal methods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_methods"},{"title":"Verification condition generator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verification_condition_generator"},{"title":"High-level verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High-level_verification"},{"title":"Verification and validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verification_and_validation"},{"title":"Compiler correctness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compiler_correctness"},{"title":"Murφ - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mur%CF%86"},{"title":"Joseph Sifakis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._Sifakis"},{"title":"IBM Israel - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM_Haifa_Labs"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about formal verification:

## Definition

Formal verification is the act of proving or disproving the correctness of a system with respect to a certain formal specification or property, using formal methods of mathematics.

## Approaches

There are several key approaches to formal verification:

1. **Model Checking**: Model checking involves a systematic and exhaustive exploration of the mathematical model. Such exploration is possible for finite models, but also for some infinite models, where infinite sets of states can be effectively represented finitely by using abstraction or taking advantage of symmetry.

2. **Deductive Verification**: This consists of generating from the system and its specifications a collection of mathematical proof obligations, the truth of which imply conformance of the system to its specification, and discharging these obligations using either proof assistants (interactive theorem provers) or automatic theorem provers.

3. **Other Methods**: Subareas of formal verification include deductive verification, abstract interpretation, automated theorem proving, type systems, and lightweight formal methods.

## Industrial Use

Formal verification is used by most or all leading hardware companies, but its use in the software industry is still languishing.(no content)This could be attributed to the greater need in the hardware industry, where errors have greater commercial significance.

## Real-World Applications

Formal methods are applied in different areas of hardware and software, including routers, Ethernet switches, routing protocols, security applications, and operating system microkernels such as seL4. There are several examples in which they have been used to verify the functionality of the hardware and software used in data centres. IBM used ACL2, a theorem prover, in the AMD x86 processor development process. Intel uses such methods to verify its hardware and firmware.

Web search results for query: "Automated planning"

Links: [{"title":"Automated planning and scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_planning_and_scheduling"},{"title":"International Conference on Automated Planning and Scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Automated_Planning_and_Scheduling"},{"title":"Category:Automated planning and scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Automated_planning_and_scheduling"},{"title":"Reactive planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reactive_planning"},{"title":"Planning Domain Definition Language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planning_Domain_Definition_Language"},{"title":"Computer-aided process planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer-aided_process_planning"},{"title":"Partial-order planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partial-order_planning"},{"title":"Satplan - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satplan"},{"title":"Planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forethought"},{"title":"Plan - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plan"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about automated planning:

## Overview

Automated planning and scheduling, sometimes denoted as simply AI planning, is a branch of artificial intelligence that concerns the realization of strategies or action sequences, typically for execution by intelligent agents, autonomous robots and unmanned vehicles.

## How It Works

Given a description of the possible initial states of the world, a description of the desired goals, and a description of a set of possible actions, the planning problem is to synthesize a plan that is guaranteed (when applied to any of the initial states) to generate a state which contains the desired goals.

## Key Planning Approaches

**Partial-Order Planning:** Partial-order planning is an approach to automated planning that maintains a partial ordering between actions and only commits ordering between actions when forced to, that is, ordering of actions is partial.

**Hierarchical Planning:** An alternative language for describing planning problems is that of hierarchical task networks, in which a set of tasks is given, and each task can be either realized by a primitive action or decomposed into a set of other tasks.

**Reactive Planning:** In artificial intelligence, reactive planning denotes a group of techniques for action selection by autonomous agents. They operate in a timely fashion and hence can cope with highly dynamic and unpredictable environments.

## Planning Languages

The Planning Domain Definition Language (PDDL) is an attempt to standardize Artificial Intelligence (AI) planning languages. It was first developed by Drew McDermott and his colleagues in 1998 mainly to make the 1998/2000 International Planning Competition (IPC) possible.

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about Constraint Satisfaction Problems:

## Definition

Constraint satisfaction problems (CSPs) are mathematical questions defined as a set of objects whose state must satisfy a number of constraints or limitations.(no content)CSPs represent the entities in a problem as a homogeneous collection of finite constraints over variables, which is solved by constraint satisfaction methods.

## Research Areas

CSPs are the subject of research in both artificial intelligence and operations research, since the regularity in their formulation provides a common basis to analyze and solve problems of many seemingly unrelated families.(no content)Constraint programming (CP) is the field of research that specifically focuses on tackling these kinds of problems.

## Complexity

CSPs often exhibit high complexity, requiring a combination of heuristics and combinatorial search methods to be solved in a reasonable time. More specifically, solving a constraint satisfaction problem on a finite domain is an NP-complete problem in general.

## Examples

Examples of problems that can be modeled as a constraint satisfaction problem include: Sudoku, crosswords, futoshiki, Kakuro (Cross Sums), Numbrix/Hidato, Zebra Puzzle, and many other logic puzzles.(no content)"Real life" examples include automated planning, lexical disambiguation, musicology, product configuration and resource allocation.

## Solution Techniques

Such problems are usually solved via search, in particular a form of backtracking or local search.(no content)There are three main algorithmic techniques for solving constraint satisfaction problems: backtracking search, local search, and dynamic programming.

1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

4. [in_progress] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [pending] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

7. **Automated planning and scheduling** (task, uses) - Application area

9. **Validity (logic)** (concept, proposes) - Novel model-theoretic account
